title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "There," said Sir David, "let the Regent climbwhen he returns from France for the head of his favourite; it is thusthat Home of Wedderburn revenges the murder of his kindred."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: The head of the Chevalier was carried toDunse, where it was fixed upon a spear at the cross, and Wedderburnexclaimed, "Thus be exalted the enemies of the house of Home!"

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "Off with his head!" exclaimed Wedderburn, who at the same instantreached the spot.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: The sword of Wedderburn had already smitten three of theChevalier's followers to the ground, and the two chiefs now contended insingle combat.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "Then on, my merry men!" cried Wedderburn, "and to-day the head of theRegent's favourite, the Chevalier of Beauty, for the head of the Earl ofHome!"

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "Hold!" exclaimed Wedderburn, grasping his arm.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "By the authority of the Regent!" interrupted Wedderburn; "dare ye,foreign minion, speak of the authority of the murderer of the Earl ofHome, while within the reach of the sword of his kinsman?"

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: To his care the Regent had committed youngCockburn, the heir of Langton, who was the nephew of Wedderburn.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: Theindignation of Wedderburn had not slumbered, and the conferring thehonours and the power that had hitherto been held by his family upon aforeigner, incensed him to almost madness.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: Lady Alison wept, and withdrew in silence; and Wedderburn paced thefloor of the gloomy hall, meditating in what manner he should mosteffectually resent the death of his kinsman.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "My murdered kinsman!" exclaimed Wedderburn, grasping the arm of theother.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: "Your errand, stranger?" said the young chief of Wedderburn, fixing asearching glance upon him as he spoke.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: Around him hung rude portraits of the chiefs ofWedderburn, and on the walls were suspended their arms and the spoils oftheir victories.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 23
author: Various
snippet: It was near midnight, on the 12th of October 1516, when a horseman,spurring his jaded steed, rode furiously down the path leading to thestrong tower of Wedderburn.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: This reason will perhaps explain why, in none of the histories of thattime, even the more particular, there is any mention made of ourancestors; while we meet with Wedderburn, Aiton, Manderston,Cowdenknows, Sprot, and other cadets of Home.

title: Bertie's Guide to Life and Mothers
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: One of the members then was a partner in one of the big law firms – it wasn't Shepherd & Wedderburn, as I recall.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: All the shades mentioned above, with the exception of the old litigants and the judges following, namely Lord Chancellor  Hatton, Mr. Justice "Johnny" Williams, Lord Chancellor Camden, Lord Chancellor Eldon, Sir John Leach, Master of the Rolls, Lord Chancellor Thurlow, Lord Chief Justice Kenyon, and Wedderburn, Lord Chancellor Loughborough, were members of Lincoln's Inn.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk,
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: We returned with them to supper, Wedderburn having continued cordial and open all that day ; his brother was always so.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: We returned with them to supper, Wedderburn having continued cordial and open all that day ; his brother was always so.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: There were John Home, and Robertson, and Wedderburn, and Robert and James Adam, and Colonel David Wedderburn, who was killed when commander of the army in Bombay, in the year [1778J He was held by his companions to be in every respect as clever and able a man as his elder brother the Chancellor, with a much more gay, popular, and social temper.

title: Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle ;
author: Carlyle, Alexander
snippet: There were J. Home, and Eobertson, and Wedderburn, and Jack Dalrymple, and Bob Adam, Ferguson, and myself.
